Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Theory, Algorithms, and Experiments for Frequency-Agile Beamforming Mesh (FabMesh)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The FCC seeks to connect 19 million unserved Americans to broadband by 2020. These rural areas have yet to be fully connected to the Internet due to wireline infrastructure costs which exceed potential revenue opportunities. Even in heavily-populated environments with sufficient wireline infrastructure, capacity issues remain in congested stadiums, disaster recovery zones, and public transportation. Each aforementioned access challenge seemingly is well-suited for wireless mesh networks, but have yet to be fully solved. However, recently, there has been a sizable growth in radios operating in diverse frequency bands (e.g., TV white spaces) with emerging multi-antenna schemes. In this project, multi-user beamforming and diverse frequency bands are leveraged to significantly build upon the flexibility originally sought by mesh networks. In doing so, frequency-agile beamforming mesh (FabMesh) networks seek to truly scale in complexity and cost according to the user population and traffic demand. The work includes three key innovations: (i) client-side, beamforming-aware, and frequency-agile protocols to improve performance and reliability of clients, using contextual information and advanced physical layer techniques, (ii) analysis of spatial reuse and capacity for media access control in mesh networks which leverage multi-user beamforming, and (iii) scalable network deployments which leverage multi-user beamforming along the backhaul and adaptation across multiple frequency bands according to network demand. The project includes a number of hands-on courses for university students at all levels, "just in time" pedagogical approaches to thousands of online students, outreach to under-represented students and communities, and key industrial collaborations to accelerate the commercial adoption of FabMesh networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching vision of the project was to leverage the diversity of multiple available frequency bands and multi-user MIMO to allow greater flexibility and scalability of wireless mesh networks. There were four main thrusts to the project: (i) We leveraged MIMO, MU-MIMO, and beamforming from the client side and from the access point side to improve the throughput and handoff of FabMesh users. (ii) We developed an understanding of how diverse frequency bands could be optimally allocated across multihop mesh topologies, focusing on a broad set of sub 6 GHz carrier frequencies. (iii) We sought to understand how the propagation and interference could be understood from the client via crowdsourcing and in-situ measurements. (iv) We developed economic frameworks for data plans, infrastructure sharing, and cost-aware offloading. 

Intellectual Merit: One of the most critical outcomes from the project is the wholistic view and interaction of throughput, delay, energy efficiency, and economic costs of multiple frequency bands under 6 GHz (specifically white space, WiFi, and cellular) in designing multihop/mesh wireless topologies of all types.  With such a full picture of sub 6 GHz bands in terms of both networking and pricing/economic factors, the project has an impact on spectral policy and multi-tier spectrum sharing. Through each of the aforementioned activites and objectives, we produced measurements from various in-field and simulated environments. For example, multiple in-field studies were performed on spectral usage in the Dallas-Fort Worth area and in Taos, NM, some of which have been relesed on the project webpage.

Broader Impacts: Our project has included the development of students at all levels from undergraduate to post doctoral positions. Through weekly group meetings, conference calls, inter-site visits, and student exchanges, the students and postdocs experienced continual feedback about their work and an exposure to diverse campus environments. Many of these students and postdocs are now working in industrial (Samsung, Intel, etc.) and academic (Portland State University, University of Albany, etc.) jobs. One of the students funded from this project went on to be the entrepreneurial lead for an I-Corps project.
